reviewText: If you know the Anno series games, then you already know Dawn of Discovery -- it was released as Anno 1404 in Europe but (for some reason) renamed for the North American release.   Like all the Anno games, it can be a little bit micro-managerial, but it's delightful nonetheless.  A good sound track and lovely graphics are definite good points, and the trade system is one of the best around.  If I had a complaint it would be that the computer players/NPCs natter at you constantly.  That could really be toned down but it's easy to handle by adjusting sound settings, too.  But it's completely possible to just get lost in this game and spend hours upon hours enjoying it.

reviewText: Anno 1404 aka Dawn of Discovery is an excellent city manegement and building game. First even though the game is relatively old (2010) the graphics are still beautiful but even more than that, what truly shines in this game is the attention to detail. Watching your workers roll barrels, or some peasants celebrating at a tavern or even the performers at the juggler's camp is highly entertaining. The gameplay is extremely satisfying with excellent depths however it's simple enough and the campaign does a good job of introducing the gameplay elements. The storyline is meh, but the campaign is still enjoyable with varied scenarios and objectives like all good strategy games. The scenarios will also add decent amount of gameplay hours after the main campaign is clocked and the continous mode will further still add more gameplay hours.\n\nIf you do buy this game and enjoy it then the Venice addon is higly recommended as it essentially add more content is an already excellent game.

reviewText: Dawn of Discovery has to be one of the greatest Trading/Building games out there. If you like Port Royale you should totally get this one. It will become addictive especially in Free Mod were you can approach your empire without the hassle of finishing a campaign chapter. The only downside is that it has no multiplayer. Dawn of Discovery : Venice does have it, but if your looking for the original look then get this one. 5/5 pyros

reviewText: Dawn of Discovery (aka Anno 1404 outside USA) is the most charming and addictive city-building game ever created. DoD has absolutely stunning graphics, whimsical art design, endearing characters, complex city-building and trade mechanics, and immense replay-ability! Oh, and the music is so good, and the sound design creates such alive environments. Everything is good about this game. I have zero complaints. Related Designs has totally outdone themselves here. This truly is sleeper hit. If you have even a slight interest in city-building and historic sim games, play this game.

reviewText: Much like its predecessor, Anno 1701, Dawn of Discovery is an addictive, fairly slow-paced, real-time resource management strategy game.  The premise of the game is that you need to fulfil the demands of your population. You harvest resources to build houses; you build houses to increase your population and secure taxes; as your population increases, their demands for other resources increase; and as you fulfil those demands, you garner greater taxes and unlock the rest of the tech tree. It's hard for me to recommend this game over Anno 1701, this plays more like an expansion than a sequel (they both use the same engine), but I can assure you you can sink many hours into this game.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The best way I can describe this game is one part tropico and one part dwarf fortress.  It's a city builder, trade management and hapiness management game.  I love nearly every bit of this game, with the exception of it's moderatley boring combat.
Luckily, combat is a relatively minor point of the game and, even though not very exciting, still works and is quite easy to grasp.

Another strong point in this games favour is it's gentle learning curve.  Dawn of Discovery introduces game ideas throughout the well crafted campaign.  It could even be said that the Campaign almost functions as a tutorial for the enormity of the game.

And enormity is what you get!  Like in Dwarf Fortress, you don't just make items.  For instance, if you want to supply your nobles with lether jerkins then you first build a farm for the cows, then a skinner, then a tanner, then ship them to the clothes maker, etc.  It is luckily somewhat more simple than DF.  A great game to scratch the itch!
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Probably one of my top 5 favorite games... period.  A sort of sim-building/strategy game with a few RPG elements.  You can grow a town and strive for whatever style you'd like.  A bit like the Civilization series, but completely different as well.  Balancing resources, building epic cities or numerous colonies on islands, expanding into the orient to build a new culture complete with their own resources/building and so on.  I get sucked into this one for hours.

reviewText: I really liked this game.  It's a fun city builder with a interesting storyline.  What I really liked about is you could build several cities in several different regions.  So you can interconnect their needs and wants.  Some regions can't manufacture certain items but another region can so you transport it over in boat.\n\n-The only negative is that in the story, with each new chapter you need to re-build your cities.  It's kind of like Tropico in that regard

The only game i paid 50$ on steam for. Couldn't launch it for few weeks, before i found a solution (non latin characters in a game folder path) and shared it with everyone else on forums. Meanwhile ubisoft didn't reply on forums or tickets and introduced a fix TWO month's later. Disgusting.

The game itself is good enough though - graphics are pretty, music is nice... gameplay however is slow, especially multiplayer since you can't speed it up.

I can't recommend it since Anno 2070 has been out for a year and its basically the same game with different graphics. But it instead if you want classical chain production strategy game.

reviewText: Has to be one of my favourite Anno game by Ubisoft. First played the game on Wii then realized Steam had this game in its library. Love the history and lore behind the game and the diplomacy measures added. Trading with the Orient is fun and trying to avoid the pirates of the sea the Corsairs. Also enjoy the free choices of the continuous mode to build your metropolis to your liking, while taxing your subjects. In the end I am aware that the game was made in 2009, however the graphics for the time are incredible and so far the game has had no noticeable bugs. Points to not having it to connect to the faulty Uplay launcher like Anno 2070.

reviewText: This game is fun, but kinda weird. It's worth giving a try if you can find a demo or get it on sale.

First impressions:
- Beautiful graphics and music, etc
- The advisors and characters are bloody annoying... I liked them better in Anno 1701

reviewText: I'm about 40hours into this game, and I bought it 4 days ago... I think, that basically says it all. It is not a RTS per se, but it will test your planning and multi-tasking skills to the limit. The game has no manual, or even a real tutorial. The campaing kind of explains a bit, but i quickly started playing the continuous mode, which is insane. Most campaign levels are 4-5hours long, and continuous never stops. I love the interface and graphic, and how great all work together. I was not familiar with the Anno series, so this is my first one. I bought it for $4.99 on the Ubisoft discount day. I don't regret it at all. This is a gem.
